title: DEF claims Lack of Privity as DEF has never entered into any contractual or debtor/creditor arrangements with the PLT. Useful?
question: Category: Collections - Limited civil. Iâ€™m being sued by a junk debt buyer. Causes of action: 1st: Breach of contract; 2nd: Common Counts, including, among others, account stated. I used the affirmative defense in my Answer.
answers:
You have posted several questions regarding this matter and I agree with Mr. Fenster that you are in over your head. Please see any attorney.

In response to your question, no, no this is not a useful defense. Buying debts and suing on them is legal.
Please don't be offended, but you are in way over your head. Get advice from a local transaction lawyer.

If you were sued in a Limited Jurisdiction case (under $25,000) and the complaint is UNVERIFIED (meaning that the plaintiff or plaintiff's representative did not sign a verification to the complaint, you can file a GENERAL DENIAL as your answer. (Form PLD-050) You should include all affirmative defenses that you know of that may be applicable. "Lack of standing" may be used to reflect that you did not have a contract or agreement with that plaintiff, and therefore the plaintiff does not have a contractual right to be paid.

If you need help with your answer, or with any other aspect of the case, seek the advice of an attorney that handles consumer debt defense. If you cannot afford to hire an attorney, see if you can find a nonprofit consumer clinic in your area. Do this before you conduct any discovery (requesting or sending documents). "Pro per" defendants cannot be taught how to conduct discovery -- it's just too complex and there's too much opportunity to get it wrong.
lack of Privity will not be a successful defense as the debt purchaser steps into the shoes of the original creditor with ALL of the rights And claims available to the original creditor.
